section.name: Trycatch
section.p: A wrapper that lets you run a set of tasks and optionally run a different set of tasks if the first set fails and yet another set after the first one has finished.
The tasks inside of the required try element will be run. If one of them should throw a BuildException several things can happen:

ul.li: If there is no catch block, the exception will be passed through to Ant.
If the property attribute has been set, a property of the given name will be set to the message of the exception.
If the reference attribute has been set, a reference of the given id will be created and point to the exception object.
If there is a catch block, the tasks nested into it will be run.

section.p: If a finally block is present, the task nested into it will be run, no matter whether the first tasks have thrown an exception or not.

tr.td: Name of a property that will receive the message of the exception that has been caught (if any)
Id of a reference that will point to the exception object that has been caught (if any)

subsection.name: Example
subsection.source:
<trycatch property="foo" reference="bar"> <try> <fail>Tada!</fail> </try>
<catch> <echo>In &lt;catch&gt;.</echo> </catch>
<finally> <echo>In &lt;finally&gt;.</echo> </finally> </trycatch>
<echo>As property: ${foo}</echo> <property name="baz" refid="bar"/> <echo>From reference: ${baz}</echo>
[trycatch] Caught exception: Tada! [echo] In <catch>. [echo] In <finally>. [echo] As property: Tada! [echo] From reference: Tada!
